clinical_study.brief_title: Development and Validation of The Post-CRT LARS Prediction Model (PORTLARS)
clinical_study.official_title: Development and Validation of a Nomogram to Predict Severe Bowel Dysfunction After Rectal Cancer Resection and Neoadjuvant Chemoradiotherapy

lead_sponsor.agency: Sixth Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-sen University

clinical_study.source: Sixth Affiliated Hospital, Sun Yat-sen University

brief_summary.textblock: Bowel dysfunction is common after a restorative rectal cancer resection. Neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy is an influential factor that impairs bowel function and quality of life. However, almost half patients who have received primary surgery with preoperative radiotherapy are able to restore a good or moderate bowel function in the long term. This multicenter observational study aims to identify the risk factors of severe bowel dysfunction after rectal cancer resection and neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy, in accordance with the LARS score, and to build a model that predicts long-term major LARS in the early stage of follow-up. Development and validation cohorts are enrolled from tertiary hospitals in China.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients with major low anterior resection syndrome (LARS score)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Over one year after restorative rectal cancer resection

arm_group.description: A primary cohort of eligible patients from the Sixth Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University is used for model derivation.
An independent cohort of consecutive patients from the Sixth Affiliated Hospital of Sun Yat-sen University is used for internal validation.
An independent cohort of eligible patients from other hospitals is used for external validation.

intervention.description: The LARS score is used for assessment of bowel dysfunction after rectal cancer resection.

study_pop.textblock: Patients who underwent preoperative long-course radiotherapy, parallel chemotherapy, and curative low anterior resection for nonmetastatic rectal cancer.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Curative low anterior resection for nonmetastatic rectal cancer
- Preoperative long-course radiotherapy and parallel chemotherapy
Exclusion Criteria:
- Death
- Metastasis or recurrence
- Postoperative radiotherapy
- Cognitive disorder
- Intestinal stoma
- Rectal cancer resection for <12 months
- Stoma reversal for <6 months
